intro: Cerasus duracina melanocarpa, commonly known as the black cherry, is a species of Prunus native to eastern North America. It is a small to medium-sized deciduous tree that typically grows to a height of 10–20 meters. The plant produces small, dark red to black berries that are edible but have a tart flavor. Its leaves are oval-shaped with a pointed tip and a smooth margin, and its bark is gray and fissured. The plant thrives in a variety of soil types but prefers well-drained, loamy soils and full sun exposure.
